content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance. This includes establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams consisting of Federal, State, and local law enforcement authorities for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders in the designated areas. The Attorney General may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas for Federal assistance, establishing criminal street gang enforcement teams for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. This includes reassigning personnel, providing funding for operations, and organizing national and regional meetings. The criminal street gang enforcement teams are established to investigate and prosecute criminal street gangs and offenders. The teams consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies, and funding is provided for their operations and meetings. The Attorney General considers criteria for designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including current and predicted levels of gang crime activity and the relationship between violent crime and criminal street gang activity. The criminal street gang enforcement teams consist of agents and officers from federal agencies, including the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives, the United States Marshals Service, and State and local law enforcement. The Attorney General considers criteria for designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas, including the extent of violent crime related to criminal street gang activity, resources committed by State and local law enforcement agencies, potential impact of increased Federal resources, and any additional criteria deemed relevant. The Attorney General is authorized to hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in designated high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. Appropriations are authorized to support this initiative. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims of crimes. Section 31702 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to hire additional prosecutors, fund technology and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and reduce backlogs in order to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims. The amendment aims to enhance coordination among law enforcement and prosecutors, provide funding for technology, equipment, and training to improve the identification and prosecution of young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations is also included in the amendment. Authorization of appropriations of $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012 is granted to establish state-wide crime prevention databases for state and local law enforcement. The Office of Justice Programs will award grants to State and local programs to establish State-wide crime prevention databases tracking criminals, arrests, prosecutions, and convictions. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose.
